executive_summary: The brewery landscape has shifted considerably over the past five years as smaller brewpubs and microbreweries have inundated the market, absorbing consumer demand from established industry giants. Still, multinational breweries continue to expand their geographic footprints and acquire some of these smaller players to diversify their portfolios. Competition among smaller breweries has intensified amid the market saturation and has been exacerbated by the rise of substitute alcoholic beverages, like ready-to-drink (RTD) cocktails. The greatest inhibitor to breweries' growth over the past five years was COVID-19, which crippled nearly half the market for beer when on-premise drinking sites were forced to shut down. As a result, brewery revenue has been declining at a CAGR of 0.5% over the past five years and is expected to fall 0.8% in 2024 alone, when revenue will reach $35.1 billion.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Brewers Fail to Sustain Growth During Volatile Conditions
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: COVID-19 presented significant challenges for breweries as key downstream markets, particularly on-premise locales, like restaurants and bars, temporarily shut down or experienced substantial operational difficulties. On-premise channels generate more than half of breweries' sales, so the abrupt closures and limited operational difficulties resulted in substantial revenue declines, particularly during the pandemic's height.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Breweries Strive to Keep Consumers on Their Toes
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: While the craft frenzy has slowed, demand for niche beers is still expanding, resulting in thousands of new brewers entering the field and causing established producers to question the longevity of their product portfolios. Though larger, multi-national producers typically benefit from some form of brand loyalty, the need to diversify portfolios and introduce new varieties is affecting brewers large and small.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The rush of new microbreweries and brewpubs to the market will persist over the next five years as companies seek to capitalize on fleeting consumer tastes, driving nascent brewers to develop their brand identities. Large, multinational breweries benefit from much greater advertising capabilities and, in many cases, strong brand loyalty, but smaller brewers will increasingly rely almost entirely on a small buy loyal local following.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: RTD beverages are set to shake up breweries
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The booming popularity of ready-to-drink (RTD) cocktails will prompt many breweries to re-evaluate their product offerings to ensure they remain competitive and in line with consumers' changing preferences. The rise in popularity of flavored malt beverages (FMBs) like spiked seltzers and teas over the past decade will likely ease, as the novelty of a new product segment wanes, requiring all but the most successful brands to invest heavily in product development or brand acquirement.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: The appeal of foreign brands eases among domestic drinkers
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: As the value of the US dollar falls over the next five years, domestic consumers will turn away from foreign beers, opting for less expensive US-made brands. Shrinking import competition will foster exports of domestic brands, particularly in areas like Vietnam and South Korea, as foreign consumers gain a taste for domestic beers.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Commodity prices will fall, but high wage costs will constrain profit
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The price of coarse grains, nonferrous metals and other materials used to brew and package beer will fall over the next five years, easing purchase costs for brewers. Profit margins won't entirely benefit from lower prices since wage costs are slated to rise as small-scale brewers with less capital continue to flood the market.

industry_definition: The Breweries industry primarily produces alcoholic beverages made from malted barley and hops such as beer, malt liquor and nonalcoholic beer. This industry excludes wine, brandy, cider and distilled beverages such as vodka and rum. Bottling purchased malt beverages and manufacturing purchased malt are also excluded from this industry.

market_segmentation.segment_description: Convenience stores in eligible states sell beer for consumption at another location. Retail operations like this are also considered "off-premise" markets.

Concerts, clubs and concession stands purchase beer for resale to consumers on-site. These markets are another form of "on-premise" establishments but typically account for a smaller share of revenue than bars and restaurants.
Breweries sell in bulk to restaurants, bars and other eating and drinking places where beer is consumed on-site. These channels are also regarded as "on-premise" markets.

market_segmentation.segment: Supermarkets, grocery stores and drug stores
market_segmentation.segment_description: Supermarkets, grocery stores and drug stores in eligible states sell beer, a trend which has proliferated over the past five years. These retailers are considered "off-premise" market channels.

This market includes licensed liquor stores that sell beer. In certain states, liquor and beer must be sold separately. In such locations, the market segment refers to "package" stores. These are another example of "off-premise" markets.

demand_determinants.determinant_description: Per capita expenditure on alcohol is closely related with demand for beer; as consumers increase their expenditure on alcohol, breweries are likely to see more sales. Breweries compete with other alcoholic beverage producers, like wineries and distilleries, for the same consumer dollars. Nevertheless, an increase in expenditure on alcohol poses a potential opportunity for breweries.

The excise tax on beer represents federal and median state taxes levied on beer, which are charged by the gallon. Brewers pass along the tax burden to wholesalers and consumers in the form of higher prices. Increases in the excise tax on beer increase the retail price of beer, typically driving consumers to less costly substitute beverages.

Consumer spending measures the total amount consumers spent on goods and services. As spending increases, drinkers are more likely to spend money on beer, as they feel confident that their current level of discretionary income.

international_trade_points.trade_description: While the craft beer boom is considered to have started in the United States, such trends are taking hold abroad, resulting in more craft brands being imported into the US.

international_trade_points.trade_title: Globalization increases domestic exposure to international brands
international_trade_points.trade_description: International brewers are able to reach consumers with greater ease through applications like social media platforms, enabling even relatively small foreign brands to gain a following among US consumers.

international_trade_points.trade_title: Favorable trade policies facilitate cross-border exports
international_trade_points.trade_description: The United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA) promotes the export of beer to Canada and Mexico by providing favorable conditions and keeping associated prices minimal, which can be a double-edged sword.

international_trade_points.trade_title: A strong US dollar weakens international demand
international_trade_points.trade_description: Beer is considered fairly costly to transport, especially internationally, and the rising value of the US dollar is resulting in domestic goods becoming relatively more expensive for foreign markets.

business_locations.location_description: More than one-fifth of all breweries are located in the West, with half the region's establishments settling down in California. Live events create a tremendous market for beer, and the West is no stranger to concerts and festivals. Hops, which are used to flavor and stabilize many beers, grow best in the Western climate.

Anheuser-Busch InBev SA/NV, D.G. Yuengling & Son Inc. and MillerCoors all have locations across the Southeast. Major population hubs and temperate weather make Florida, Georgia and other Southeastern states a quintessential location for breweries.

Major urban centers like Philadelphia and New York City are known for their extensive network of bars and breweries. A large population of young adults in Mid-Atlantic cities increases the appeal of beer, drawing breweries in.

regulations_points.regulation_title: US ALCOHOL AND TOBACCO TAX AND TRADE BUREAU (TTB)
regulations_points.regulation_description: The TTB regulates wine production, labeling and federal excise taxation. Compliance with TTB standards ensures standardized labeling and accurate alcohol content disclosure, fostering consumer trust.

State-specific ABC laws dictate wine sales, production and distribution, creating operational variances nationwide. For example, California allows direct-to-consumer sales, enhancing the winery tourism model, whereas states like Utah impose stricter controls.

Wineries must comply with FDA regulations governing food safety and labeling standards. Compliance might require additional investments in labeling and process controls, but it safeguards public health and mitigates the risks of costly recalls or legal issues.

EPA regulations oversee the environmental impacts of wineries, such as pesticide use, waste disposal and water management. Compliance promotes sustainable practices and may involve adopting eco-friendly technologies, which can raise operational costs but benefit the environment.

regulations_points.regulation_title: Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) Regulations
regulations_points.regulation_description: OSHA ensures safe working environments in wineries, covering equipment operation, chemical handling and ergonomics. Compliance helps prevent workplace accidents and legal penalties, fostering better employee safety and potentially lowering insurance costs.

concentration_points.concentration_description: Mergers and acquisitions have created large leading breweries like AB InBev.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Successful brewers shift to keep up with consumers
concentration_points.concentration_description: Large brewers are developing new beers resembling craft beers to keep up with demand.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Craft breweries gaining strength in numbers
concentration_points.concentration_description: Nearly 3,000 new craft breweries have entered in the last 5 years, fragmenting the industry.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: THE INFLUX OF NEW, SMALLER BREWERS RESULTS IN GREATER AVERAGE WAGE SPENDING
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Nearly 3,000 new breweries, primarily small-scale, have opened over the past five years, causing average costs to hike. Small breweries are more labor-intensive and require employees with more specialized knowledge.

To avoid volatile input costs, breweries establish long-term contracts with suppliers. Larger breweries are more likely to negotiate cost-effective contracts, as they typically have long-standing relationships with major suppliers and large purchasing power to command lower prices.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: The commercial brewing process is largely mechanized, demanding a substantial level of investment in capital equipment. To meet quality standards, equipment must be continually maintained and repaired.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_title: RISING HEALTH CONSCIOUSNESS DRIVES INNOVATION IN BEER
capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Rising health consciousness is prompting breweries to create low-calorie, low-alcohol and gluten-free options to satisfy demand for healthier choices. This innovation attracts health-conscious consumers and expands the market by offering products catering to various dietary restrictions and fitness goals.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_title: BREWERIES SUPPORT THE CLIMATE THROUGH SUSTAINABLE PACKAGING
capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Climate change is compelling breweries to adopt sustainable packaging, such as biodegradable cans or reusable containers, to reduce their environmental footprint. Consumers' growing preference for eco-friendly practices makes these innovations ethically sound and commercially advantageous, enhancing brand loyalty and attracting environmentally-conscious customers.

volatility_points.volatility_description: For years, craft breweries profited off a new generation of drinkers with more eclectic tastes. But as quickly as consumers flocked toward craft beer, they have begun to transition to other unique alcoholic beverages.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Sub-Premium Brands Take The Lead When Pockets Are Empty
volatility_points.volatility_description: Brewers can typically temper economic slumps by selling more sub-premium, or low-cost beverages. In the same vein, when disposable income levels rise, consumers trade up to super-premium, high-margin beers.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Trade Fluctuates Alongside The US Dollar
volatility_points.volatility_description: Exporting beer is a moderately significant revenue stream for larger brewers and has been rising in prominence in recent years as the smaller breweries of.

FAQs.question: How is your company impacted by the threat of imported beer brands?
FAQs.answer: Imported beer brands can boost competition, potentially losing market share if local breweries can't match their pricing, variety or perceived quality. The presence of imported beers can demand local breweries to innovate and differentiate their products, boosting production costs.

FAQs.question: Does your company have a diverse product portfolio with a mix of premium and budget-friendly brands?
FAQs.answer: Breweries with a mix of products based on price point are better able to adapt to shifting consumer demand, particularly during periods of economic disruption.

FAQs.question: Has your company explored options like mergers or acquisitions to broaden your customer base and secure more stable supply chain contracts?
FAQs.answer: Merger and acquisition activity is common among larger breweries that increasingly seek to acquire small, successful craft breweries to cater to changing consumer preferences. Private equity and venture capital firms increasingly invest in successful craft breweries, providing the capital needed to scale production, expand distribution or innovate product lines.

FAQs.question: Has your company been exposed to volatile input prices?
FAQs.answer: Breweries often confront volatility in input prices, particularly for key ingredients like barley, wheat and hops. Fluctuations in agricultural markets can significantly impact production costs. Energy prices also add to the uncertainty, with changes in fuel and electricity costs directly affecting brewing, bottling and distribution processes.

FAQs.question: Has your company adopted automation technologies to reduce production costs?
FAQs.answer: While the standard process of making beer has experienced essentially no major change throughout history, many companies have invested in automation processes for critical phases of the brewing process, including mashing, lautering, boiling and fermenting, in an attempt to reduce operational costs. Modern brewing plants increasingly use brewing, fermenting and conditioning processes that are automatic-computer-controlled or semi-automatic-controlled via a central control panel. Such practices have allowed larger breweries to reduce wage costs.

FAQs.question: Have you used trade associations and other interest groups to stay abreast of changing policies and regulations?
FAQs.answer: Breweries often engage with trade associations, like the Brewers Association, which provide important information on current laws, policy changes and industry trends impacting their operational environment. Interest groups, like the American Craft Spirits Association, serve as advocates for breweries, lobbying for favorable policies and regulations and providing essential network opportunities.

FAQs.question: How have volatile tariff hikes impacted demand for your products in international markets?
FAQs.answer: Though other alcoholic products experienced tariff hikes amid the former presidency's trade wars, breweries have largely been shielded from such volatility. Still, breweries benefit from tariffs on imported beers, which result in slightly higher selling prices than domestic brands.

FAQs.question: How is your profit impacted by economic downturns?
FAQs.answer: Economic downturns often result in lower consumer spending, negatively impacting breweries' profit by reducing sales volume and revenue. Recession periods may push breweries to reduce costs, possibly compromising quality or leading to layoffs, which can further impact profit and potentially harm their market reputation.

FAQs.question: How does input price volatility impact your profit?
FAQs.answer: Higher price volatility of critical components like barley, hops or energy can significantly disrupt breweries' production costs, squeezing their profit, especially if they don't have an effective strategy to hedge the price risks. Input price volatility can lead to price hikes for their products, negatively impacting demand and reducing breweries' sales and profit.

FAQs.question: What is your current marketing strategy to attract customers and introduce new beer brands? How do your strategies compare to those of your competitors, large and small?
FAQs.answer: Beer brands encounter strong consumer loyalty. When introducing a new brand, breweries large and small must ensure branding through label design, and marketing is sufficient to ensure success in a brand-centric market. It may still take years for a specific brand to catch on with the general public.

FAQs.question: Does your company have strong, established distribution channels? Do you distribute your beer internally or use a separate company? How can you cultivate these relationships?
FAQs.answer: Larger breweries generally have well-established, nationwide distribution channels. New entrants must have access to distribution networks, including wholesale distributors, to get their beer sold at restaurants, bars and other retail locations.

FAQs.question: How do you maintain product quality? Do you have systems in place to keep standards high and continually updating?
FAQs.answer: Innovative product flavors, bottle designs and limited-edition promotions help breweries differentiate their beer from other comparable products.

FAQs.question: How does a drop in the TWI impact your business? Are there other areas or markets that you can rely on when the TWI is high or volatile?
FAQs.answer: A drop in the TWI can make breweries' raw material imports costlier, potentially impacting profit. They can strategize to source locally or may boost product pricing to offset this. When the TWI is high or volatile, breweries can focus on domestic markets or explore alternative markets with lower currency risks. Also, they can lean into markets where craft and locally produced beers are popular to maintain revenue streams.

FAQs.question: How does a boost in demand for wineries impact demand for your brewery? Does your brewery endure external competition from other alcoholic beverage producers?
FAQs.answer: Breweries have experienced heightened competition from alternative alcoholic beverage producers like wineries and distilleries. A boost in demand for wineries may impact breweries negatively if consumers shift preferences and substitute beer for wine. However, it can also stimulate interest in alcohol overall, potentially benefiting breweries.

FAQs.question: How does a boost in per capita expenditure on alcohol impact your business? Do you have a diversified product portfolio with products in varying price segments?
FAQs.answer: As expenditure on alcohol increases, smaller breweries with specialized, more expensive options can capitalize. Having a mix of premium and bargain brands allows breweries to adapt to shifts in spending on alcoholic beverages. For instance, many consumers opt for lower-priced options during economic downturns.
